text:
Want to help save the planet?  Here are 6 things every individual can do to save the Earth:
1.  Go VEGAN (food, clothes, accessories, toiletries, furniture etc.)
2.  Consume products LESS and become an INFORMED consumer.  
   -  Don't buy anything new (except if necessary, like medicine or contact lenses).  You can buy basically everything USED or make it yourself.  
   -  Do your RESEARCH before buying anything.  Many products are destroying the environment via the extraction of raw materials, the production process, transportation etc.  Also production lines are full of human labor abuses.  Do your RESEARCH if you must buy something.  Remember, your purchase of a product acts to support that company and everything that went into that product.
   - If you don't know 100% how a product was made at each and every step, then do NOT buy the product.  You could be unknowingly supporting the extinction of orangutans in Indonesia (ex. palm oil) or the destruction of the Amazon Rainforest (ex. beef).  No joke.  Stop buying products unless you are 100% informed.  Don't be selfish.  You  don't need most products.  Buy it used at eBay/Craigslist/Goodwill or make it yourself instead of contributing to the destruction of the planet.
          - Check if the product has any certifications, such as:  RainforestAlliance, FairTrade, RSPO - Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, USDA Organic etc.
   - Stop buying via Amazon!!!  It has rampant human rights abuses that have been clearly reported on many times, including abuses and neglect during COVID-19.  In addition, despite some of its 'climate pledges', Amazon has a terrible negative impact on the environment.  Think factories, energy-usages, packing for all of those boxes, carbon emissions for the trucks that deliver them etc.  If you buy via Amazon you are supporting human rights abuses and environmental degradation.  Do you really need that product?  Just buy it used or at least directly form the actual company.  Don't be selfish, be responsible.
3.  Go plastic and packaging free.  Don't buy anything with non-compostable packaging, or that's made of non-environmental material.  If you do, make sure it's recyclable and recycle it properly.
4.  ADOPT and REDUCE family sizes.  Humans have overpopulated the world and are destroying the environment as a result.  The human population is almost at 8 billion.  We need to intelligently and voluntarily work to get our numbers down to at least half of that.  It is a very personal issue, but please consider adopting children instead of creating new children.  If having biological children, consider smaller family sizes.  
   - Donate money and/or volunteer at organizations that support women's rights and literacy.  On average, women's illiteracy rates are inverse to the number of children they have.  I.e. the number of children a woman has decreases as she becomes literate and more educated.  Here are some ideas:  Room to Read, World Literacy Foundation, Malala Fund, UNICEF, Campaign for Female Education (CAMFED), Afghan Institute of Learning, Invest in Girls, Educate Girls, AGE Africa, Asante Africa Foundation, She‚Äôs the First, Forum for African Women Educationalists (FAWE).
5. VOTE and become politically informed.  Make sure to stay politically informed and pressure your local, state and national representatives to support issues and legislation that save and protect the environment and species.  VOTE during elections.
6. Use only RENEWABLE energy and use LESS of it.  
   - Buy carbon offsets from a reliable company for your yearly energy usage.
   - Stop flying unless absolutely necessary (and buy carbon offsets if you do).  Walk, bike, ride a velomobile, use public transportation instead of gas-powered cars.
   - See if your energy company has an option for you to buy green energy or support green energy initiatives.
   - Install your own renewable energy sources, like solar panels.
   - Be conscious throughout your day and use as little energy as possible.  Ex. instead of turning on the heat, just wear a few more layers and close the windows.

We can save the planet if everyone just does their part.  Everyone please act!

Check out this presentation for more information on human impacts on the environment and what you can do to help:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YP83Qz6TabM

author: Monotonous Insomniac

text:
¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† It's not necessarily good to ignore those that oppose an opinion. The original poster of the primary comment is most likely deriving their hate for being autistic from how they're treated in society, not because of their direct neurological makeup. Any population that is discriminated against will have significantly higher rates of self-doubt, and many turn to hating themselves, assuming that they're the issue.

It's even incredibly common for those of high intelligence to feel the same way; that their mindset is a curse. But clearly, being highly intelligent is an objective advantage. 

Similarly, those that are of minority sexualities and gender identities feel the same ways. 

Therefore, this highlights issues with society itself and its structure, not an issue inherently the result of the person, their general biology, or their neurology.

Unless one can identify issues inherent to being autistic, and those issues significantly outweigh and impact the person compared to environmental factors, such as how one may be treated by others, then it's irrational to assume being autistic as a curse.

Also, when you take into account that various types of ASD are most likely evolutionary developments and/or a result of natural selection, it wouldn't make sense for it to be a curse objectively.
author: Saturn

text: ¬†@Saturn¬† You can't force a person on the Spectrum to take pride in having it. And no, I'm tired of blaming society for my problems. Typical victimhood mentality thats being pushed in universities aka indoctrination camps.
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text: ¬†@Saturn¬† https://monotonousinsomniac.com/2020/08/25/my-honest-thoughts-on-having-aspergers-syndrome/
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text: ¬†@Saturn¬† Yeah I don't have a severe form of it and have a useless degree from a university (though im feeling more confused than ever with what I want to do). But to this day I have no drivers license (cause my brain struggles with driving), still live with my parents, have trouble with organizing, struggle with group convo, and obsess too much over things. There were times in my life where having it felt like torture such as elementary school.
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text:
¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† Literally everything detailed in that link highlights issues with the structure of society: 

Sensory sensitivity is the result of an artificial, therefore, man-made environment. Sensory difficulties are seen in various other animals, and are likely to be evolutionary advantages in a natural environment. 

Difficulty socialising to a certain extent is inherent, but the anxiety, possible depression, and how people treat you is the result of those treating you that way.

Vehicles are also artificial, and humans aren't naturally made to drive them.

A daily routine can be bland, and this one can be an inherent issue with being autistic at times. However, the desire for these routines is derived from hunter-gatherer societal environments, and tend to work much better there.

You fail to mention any points where being autistic is any significant, inherent disadvantage. You only seem to detail issues with how society is structured.

Autism undoubtedly has evolutionary roots. There's a reason autistic people tend to excel at pattern-recognition, attention to detail, long-term memory, fluid intelligence, and some forms of creativity.

Society is biased towards the majority, and like I said before, those of high intelligence, according to your logic, experience certain failures because they're highly intelligent, and therefore, should have their high intelligence cured.

Should we also focus to cure homosexuality and make those with dark skin of a whiter complexion? After all, these minorities also experience significant issues relating to mental health and various life opportunities.
author: Saturn

text:
¬†@Saturn¬† 
<Sensory sensitivity is the result of an artificial, therefore, man-made environment. Sensory difficulties are seen in various other animals, and are likely to be evolutionary advantages in a natural environment.> 

So what are you going to do about it? Here in the U.S., there's at least the option of homeschooling so that kids can be brought up in a more quiet environment and avoid the noises at a regular school. As much as I don't feel comfortable listening to the fire alarm, you can't just take it away in order to create a more comfortable environment for Autistic people. What's the alternative? What about loud noises such as crowd noises, cheering, dog barking, and screaming? That doesn't sound artificial if you ask me and the first sentence sounds confusing.

<Difficulty socialising to a certain extent is inherent, but the anxiety, possible depression, and how people treat you is the result of those treating you that way.>

Basically, you're claiming I'm experiencing interpersonal oppression, which to me, isn't something that's going to help me move forward. So it's not my fault people back in elementary school made a big deal about me saying hello? It's not my fault I run away from certain people when they greeted me? It's not my fault I can't group converse? Cause from my experiences, I don't see how it is not my fault and I shouldn't hold myself accountable. I still feel it's useless always blaming other people for my struggles.

<A daily routine can be bland, and this one can be an inherent issue with being autistic at times. However, the desire for these routines is derived from hunter-gatherer societal environments, and tend to work much better there.>

And to me, routines tend to be bland. Especially if you're sitting in desks all day and getting burned out from doing homework and trying to pay attention to dry content. If anything, it makes me comfortable but not happy and can stop me from thinking about things that will impact my life such as my future and becoming more independent. 

< Vehicles are also artificial, and humans aren't naturally made to drive them.> 

So how would you change that? Without vehicles, it would be hard to get to places faster without exercising or exploiting animals. I can't live alone in the suburbs, a small town, or in most places without a car. I can't get outside the house unless my parents are available to drive me or I blow cash on a Uber or Lyft. I have been on several public transit systems and I see the limitations of public transport and how driving can be more superior to it. 

<You fail to mention any points where being autistic is any significant, inherent disadvantage. You only seem to detail issues with how society is structured.>

I've already hinted that executive functioning (which affects my driving and organization) and inability to socialize were some of the disadvantages I have that relate to my disability.

<Autism undoubtedly has evolutionary roots. There's a reason autistic people tend to excel at pattern-recognition, attention to detail, long-term memory, fluid intelligence, and some forms of creativity.>

What's your definition of intelligence? Not everyone has the same definition of it.


<Society is biased towards the majority, and like I said before, those of high intelligence, according to your logic, experience certain failures because they're highly intelligent, and therefore, should have their high intelligence cured.>

How exactly will you restructure society so that it accomodates Autistic people? Surely you're not gonna go the route where political correctness and cancel culture thrives cause so far, its been disastrous and no wonder Blexit exists and Dave Rubin left the left. So by your definition, Autism equals intelligence even though there's way more to it than inteligence. And what do you mean by "certain failures because they're highly intelligent"?

And are you on the Spectrum as well? Cause idk what environment you were brought up in.
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text:
¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† 

The sensory issues are different per individual. However, the vast majority of sounds and sensory input distressing for us is often that of artificial origin. Natural sounds can be much louder and sometimes painful, but this would've served as a significant advantage in hunter-gatherer societies, and may even be an evolutionary development, therefore, shouldn't be blamed as an inherent issue.

No, it's not your fault that people made a big deal when you said hello. How could it be? Their reaction and how they deal with it is down to them, therefore, it's an issue with them taking it as a big deal.

It's not necessarily your fault when you run away out of anxiety. Anxiety is a behaviour that occurs due to a stressful environment, and isn't inherent to being autistic, however. This should be improved upon though, indeed.

What matters is why you became anxious in the first place. Did people treat you poorly? Obviously, that's on them, as they willingly apply their behaviour.

Did you become anxious because of what you did somehow? Then sure, it's your fault.

However, being autistic doesn't cause anxiety and depression.

I agree with your opinion on routines, although there are certainly things you can do to make your routine more enjoyable.

You have a point for vehicles. However, I'm not trying to prove that it's not a disadvantage; I'm saying that blaming autism as an inherent issue doesn't make sense.

I mentioned "fluid intelligence" to be more specific. It has its own definition. If you'd like, I can provide evidence of the advantages I mentioned.

I'm not saying that society should immediately be restructured. It should certainly be restructured over time, however. I'm merely making a point that blaming autism as an issue in itself for everything you've mentioned is irrational.

Also, highly intelligent people may often experience social issues due to their different mindsets that don't fit in with the norms of society, along with potentially having more difficult with cognitive empathy due to a more logic-orientated mindset. The same issues can be applied to every minority population, but for different reasons.
author: Saturn

text:
¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† In addition to my previous reply, because I did forget to mention it: 

Yes, I'm autistic, struggle immensely throughout life, and work on improving what I struggle with.

However, I don't blame being autistic as an inherent issue, because I still recognise that being a minority alone causes significant issues, as society is biased towards the majority, and that many issues I experience, whilst exaggerated by being autistic, aren't necessarily a direct consequence of being autistic.

Yes, certain sensory input can cause issues, my more literal style of socialising causes conflict with other methods of socialising, and issues with executive function impairs various aspects of my life. 

I don't deny my difficulties, nor am I saying that not being autistic wouldn't make life easier. At the same time, I'd rather be autistic.

I just don't see the logic in blaming being autistic as if it's the source to all of my problems, nor do I see the logic in you doing the same for your problems. All I see is a correlation, but correlation doesn't always equal causation.
author: Saturn

text:
¬†@Saturn¬†
<The sensory issues are different per individual. However, the vast majority of sounds and sensory input distressing for us is often that of artificial origin. Natural sounds can be much louder and sometimes painful, but this would've served as a significant advantage in hunter-gatherer societies, and may even be an evolutionary development, therefore, shouldn't be blamed as an inherent issue.>

And I had a hard time dealing with natural sounds such as cheering which is why I didn't like school assemblies and why I quit performing in a school band before the stage performance and why I had the other person tied with me go on stage for the spelling bee instead of me. Basically stage fright coupled with the dislike of noise made it hard for me. 

 <No, it's not your fault that people made a big deal when you said hello. How could it be? Their reaction and how they deal with it is down to them, therefore, it's an issue with them taking it as a big deal.> 

Why is it an issue? Look I used to think this way but then I realized that you can't expect everyone to understand my disability. Especially teachers since they're too busy trying to teach a big class of students with different backgrounds and their probably are still paying off their student loans as well hence they don't have the time or motivation to research Autism. I mean, couples make it a big deal when their baby utters the first word unless you see that as an issue as well. And yes, it's my fault considering I never said hello back in those times due to shyness.

<It's not necessarily your fault when you run away out of anxiety. Anxiety is a behaviour that occurs due to a stressful environment, and isn't inherent to being autistic, however. This should be improved upon though, indeed 

What matters is why you became anxious in the first place. Did people treat you poorly? Obviously, that's on them, as they willingly apply their behaviour.>

It's a combination of both shyness and anxiety because I had a fight or flight reaction of running away from certain people when they greeted me. It's like when you see a cat in your backyard and you come out and then the cat runs away. It's not entirely the fault of the people. They didn't do much wrong to me before. Heck, I even remember running and locking myself in my parents room when family members came over even though I have nothing against them.

<I agree with your opinion on routines, although there are certainly things you can do to make your routine more enjoyable.>

During this plandemic, I realized how important it is to have a variety in life rather than doing the same dull thing over and over. I think how much time I spent in college and how much I could've spent on trying to find my talents, exercise more, and find things that bring me actual happiness. There are things I still regret not doing before I became an adult and to an extent, pre-plandemic and I feel that me getting too comfortable with routines is what held me back in not doing those things.

<You have a point for vehicles. However, I'm not trying to prove that it's not a disadvantage; I'm saying that blaming autism as an inherent issue doesn't make sense.>

Well what else is there to blame? My Asperger's structures my brain in a way where it's hard for me to practice executive functioning skills such as multitasking, which in turn makes it hard for me to drive. Especially on the freeways. As much as it made me mad how a driving instructor slapped me on the hand for making a mistake, I can't deny it was his natural instincts that made him do that and I probably would've done the same if I were in his place. 

<I'm not saying that society should immediately be restructured. It should certainly be restructured over time, however. I'm merely making a point that blaming autism as an issue in itself for everything you've mentioned is irrational>

Well I've got to take responsibility somehow and acknowledge my weaknesses. Blaming society for my problems doesn't do good. And how should society be restructured? If anything, I hope it's nothing like The Great Reset or Agenda 21/2030.

<I mentioned "fluid intelligence" to be more specific. It has its own definition. If you'd like, I can provide evidence of the advantages I mentioned.>

Go ahead.

<Also, highly intelligent people may often experience social issues due to their different mindsets that don't fit in with the norms of society, along with potentially having more difficult with cognitive empathy due to a more logic-orientated mindset. The same issues can be applied to every minority population, but for different reasons.>


Like what mindsets?
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text:
¬†@Saturn¬† 

<society is biased towards the majority.>

That's just the way it is everywhere. Try living in China as an Uyghur, in South Africa as a White person, or just about most places in the world today without wearing a mask. It looks harder than it is to be Autistic in America.

<I don't deny my difficulties, nor am I saying that not being autistic wouldn't make life easier. At the same time, I'd rather be autistic.>

Good for you even though sometimes I feel that I could use an executive functioning brain or a brain that allows me to socialize and understand conversations better.

<I just don't see the logic in blaming being autistic as if it's the source to all of my problems, nor do I see the logic in you doing the same for your problems. All I see is a correlation, but correlation doesn't always equal causation.>

I don't blame all of the struggles I've faced in life on my disability. Just the ones that tend to relate to my disability. What do you suggest I do instead?
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text:
‚Äã¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† ‚Äã 

In reply to your first comment:

Stage fright can be the result of many things. 

Stage fright is especially common in the neurotypical population, so it's far from likely that it's caused because you're autistic.

I can understand that certain sounds may cause the stage fright though.

However, of course it's an issue to be worked on.

------------------------------

It's not about them understanding your neurodiversity. It's about them understanding and utilising basic respect. Again, I can apply the same logic to other minority populations: 

Others don't have enough time to understand culture common among black people, therefore, it should be up to the black person to normalise themselves and act typically around white people, and is also the fault of the black person for acting differently in the first place.

Others don't have enough time to understand homosexuality either, and it's then the fault of that homosexual person for acting and expressing themselves in a stereotypical gay manner, of which then caused them to be rejected. After all, they don't fit in, nor does everyone have time to try and understand them, therefore, the gay person should change, and those other people aren't at fault for discriminating against that individaul.

Others don't have enough time to understand the overly-analytical mindset of various highly intelligent people, therefore, it's the fault of that highly intelligent person if they act in a highly intelligent, logical manner, and should then make efforts to change themselves to conform more to societal norms. Because, in the end, we can't just expect other people to change or make efforts to understand differences when they're already preoccupied.

Do you see how silly that sounds?

------------------------------

You don't necessarily have to blame anything. Although, driving vehicles is something being autistic causes deficiencies in for some individuals.

At the same time, humans aren't made to drive vehicles, therefore, I believe blaming being autistic is illogical, as when autistic neurology evolved, there were absolutely no vehicles to be driven at the time.

------------------------------

Blaming society doesn't mean that one ignores that they can improve on their weaknesses. Just like everyone, even neurotypicals, we have to improve on our weaknesses because of our neurology. Similarly, neurotypicals also have to improve on some of their weaknesses in life because of their neurology. It goes both ways.

Like I said; I acknowledge that I have weaknesses, and that I even work to improve them. That doesn't mean I can't acknowledge the objectivity of autism falling under the social model of disability, mostly due to how society is structured for the majority.

I know society is what primarily restricts me, yet I still work around that.

I also simply don't see the logic in blaming a type of neurodivergence for issues when that specific type of neurodivergence is what has contributed to many of society's technological developments.

------------------------------
Use a search engine to discover the following studies. It should be a simple copy and paste:

"Superior fluid intelligence in children with Asperger‚Äôs disorder" - enhanced fluid intelligence due to ASC.

"Europe PMC - Talent in autism: hyper-systemizing, hyper-attention to detail and sensory hypersensitivity" - enhanced systemizing, attention to detail, and sensory sensitivity due to ASC.

(unrelated to my previous claims, but good to read nonetheless) "People with autism possess greater ability to process information, study suggests" - superior information processing in relation to minor and important details due to ASC.

"Brosnan M, Lewton M, Ashwin C. Reasoning on the Autism Spectrum: A Dual Process Theory Account. J Autism Dev Disord. 2016;46(6):2115-2125. doi:10.1007/s10803-016-2742-4" - evidence of more deliberative decision making, which correlates with logical reasoning ability

"ScienceDirect - Long-term memory and levels-of-processing in autism" - displays superiority in certain areas of long-term memory in autistic individuals, but also deficiencies in other areas

------------------------------

You know, the typical overly-analytical mindset that causes them to not fit in? Or other mindsets, such as being overly-attentive to bigger and smaller details, of which may also cause them to appear abnormal in social contexts.

Highly intelligent people will simply experience significantly more rejection literally because they're more intelligent and express themselves more logically. Now, I don't know about you, but that certainly seems like an issue with other people.

------------------------------

In reply to this comment:

Sure, it's like that everywhere. However, that doesn't mean that such an attitude towards those in the minority is necessarily appropriate.

------------------------------

Sometimes I feel the same way, but then again, I'm sure some neurotypicals wish they were autistic at times.

------------------------------

Right. But again, that's more or less assuming that correlation equals causation. Certain difficulties can be exaggerated by you being autistic, but at the same time, that doesn't necessarily mean that being autistic is to blame for them existing in the first place.

Since autism is essentially your entire personality, aren't you then technically blaming yourself?
author: Saturn

text:
¬†@Saturn¬† <I can understand that certain sounds may cause the stage fright though.>

Yes without the loud sounds, the stage fright would've been more manageable so I can't deny sounds have enhanced the stage fright to a new level compared to stage fright that is typical. It's more about being scared of people cheering for me in support rather than the fear of messing up and embarrassing myself on stage hence I do see a connection with my disability. The only crowd sound I could handle back then was clapping.

<Others don't have enough time to understand culture common among black people, therefore, it should be up to the black person to normalise themselves and act typically around white people, and is also the fault of the black person for acting differently in the first place.

Others don't have enough time to understand homosexuality either, and it's then the fault of that homosexual person for acting and expressing themselves in a stereotypical gay manner, of which then caused them to be rejected. After all, they don't fit in, nor does everyone have time to try and understand them, therefore, the gay person should change, and those other people aren't at fault for discriminating against that individaul.

Others don't have enough time to understand the overly-analytical mindset of various highly intelligent people, therefore, it's the fault of that highly intelligent person if they act in a highly intelligent, logical manner, and should then make efforts to change themselves to conform more to societal norms. Because, in the end, we can't just expect other people to change or make efforts to understand differences when they're already preoccupied.

Do you see how silly that sounds?>

I'm just putting myself in the position of people who have failed to understand me so I don't see it as silly as you think it is. Like how would you ensure more people understand and be more accepting? I can't think of a solution considering how people are in different situations such as having their own daily struggles, how busy they are, and their own strong beliefs such as Christianity (since you mentioned homosexuals) so I'm interested in seeing what your solution to this is. Interesting how you brought up blacks. Contrary to what BLM says, anti-black racism in America today isn't as bad as BLM makes it out to be and that Blexit has pointed out problems within the black community that has been a factor in holding the community back such as black-on-black crime and the lack of fathers in households. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cuT-g9amfPw 

<You don't necessarily have to blame anything. Although, driving vehicles is something being autistic causes deficiencies in for some individuals.

At the same time, humans aren't made to drive vehicles, therefore, I believe blaming being autistic is illogical, as when autistic neurology evolved, there were absolutely no vehicles to be driven at the time.>

And humans aren't natural swimmers either. And I believe all human beings (even within the Autism community) are created differently and not equal. In the case of driving, some people have managed to adapt and learn to drive while others never did or have but just don't drive well. In my case, I feel my disability made it more difficult than normal to learn how to drive compared to my neurotypical younger brother who already has his own license. I will also say my lack of motivation to do so also played a part. However, I also feel my lack of motivation arose when I was in college and too used to a college-rest routine hence I was too used to studying on a daily basis and using my limited interest as an escape to even think about driving hence I see that as a another connection to my disability. Not to mention my lack of trust in myself in the idea of being responsible for a car. In essence, it doesn't entirely make sense for me to blame my struggle to drive on human nature as a whole considering all humans are different regarding who they are and how they adapt to changes over time. I suggest watching this interesting part of a lecture that does a good job explaining how humans aren't born equal:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hAEdgPRpvkU

<Blaming society doesn't mean that one ignores that they can improve on their weaknesses. Just like everyone, even neurotypicals, we have to improve on our weaknesses because of our neurology. Similarly, neurotypicals also have to improve on some of their weaknesses in life because of their neurology. It goes both ways.

Like I said; I acknowledge that I have weaknesses, and that I even work to improve them. That doesn't mean I can't acknowledge the objectivity of autism falling under the social model of disability, mostly due to how society is structured for the majority.

I know society is what primarily restricts me, yet I still work around that.>

And for some people on the Spectrum, it can be overwhelming to work around it and their disability makes it just as hard if not harder than society makes it hard.

<I also simply don't see the logic in blaming a type of neurodivergence for issues when that specific type of neurodivergence is what has contributed to many of society's technological developments.>

And how do you know that Autism was the main driving force and not a correlation rather than an outside variable such as being homeschooled, properly mentored, or something environmental?

<"Europe PMC - Talent in autism: hyper-systemizing, hyper-attention to detail and sensory hypersensitivity" - enhanced systemizing, attention to detail, and sensory sensitivity due to ASC.>

Okay I admit I do have attention to detail and while I experienced benefits, I do experience struggles with it. 
I also noticed in one of the other studies you mentioned noted in the end that STEM students have more Autistic traits than those in social sciences in humanities and interestingly enough, my degree is in social science. rather than STEM.

<You know, the typical overly-analytical mindset that causes them to not fit in? Or other mindsets, such as being overly-attentive to bigger and smaller details, of which may also cause them to appear abnormal in social contexts.

Highly intelligent people will simply experience significantly more rejection literally because they're more intelligent and express themselves more logically. Now, I don't know about you, but that certainly seems like an issue with other people.> 

I haven't experienced rejection for anything like that or heard of it for other people on the Spectrum. Have you yourself experienced it? If anything, my social skills and my reaction to noises are what stood me out from the crowd rather than my intelligence.

<Sure, it's like that everywhere. However, that doesn't mean that such an attitude towards those in the minority is necessarily appropriate>

Basically one of the reasons why I'm against the new normal and why people should be skeptical of it. It just creates another culture of conformity where the people who don't conform are targeted in addition to the fact that it goes against human nature and violates human rights for everyone regardless of their background. 

<Sometimes I feel the same way, but then again, I'm sure some neurotypicals wish they were autistic at times.>

Then if that's true (which I haven't heard a neurotypical think that way yet), it's cause the media, especially Greta Thunberg, tends to romanticize it nowadays and a lot of people link it with intelligence and suspect historical figures have it while not acknowledging the fact that it is a Spectrum and that the severe forms of it are ones that can make life a major struggle for the individual and their families and peers. This in turn causes people to make an association and assume Autism was the main driving force behind their intelligence and success and think that becoming Autistic will make you the next Einstein or whatever historical genius they can think of.

<Since autism is essentially your entire personality, aren't you then technically blaming yourself?>

I don't see my disability as something that defines me nor my entire personality. I see it as a part of me that has an effect on my daily life and now since thankfully I'm not in college anymore, I'm looking to improve my weaknesses and myself as a person and discover talents and see how I can put them to good use. So I do somewhat blame myself since I recognize I am at fault for some things and I like to go into detail how I became at fault for things.
author: Monotonous Insomniac

text:
¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† 

Then your stage fright seems valid.

------------------------------

The world isn't the United States. I'm not referring to discrimination in specific locations any more than I'm talking about such issues globally. I'm also using the discrimination these groups may receive as examples, not to assume that these groups are discriminated against constantly on a global scale. My point is simply that these groups are sometimes discriminated against because of the cultures common among them, and their cultures essentially develop their personality. 

However, these people clearly shouldn't normalise themselves for the mere sake of being misunderstood. People don't only need to understand these specific groups, but be more accepting of differences in general, as the primitive mindset of rejecting differences because they could be potential threats to group stability isn't required in modern society, nor does it have any logical benefit.

Fact of the matter is that those in any minority group are significantly more likely to be rejected. It can even get to the points of physical abuse merely because they're minority groups.

------------------------------

I'm merely pointing out that autism isn't the cause of these issues and merely exaggerates problems that already exist. If the cause of these problems were eliminated, then being autistic couldn't exaggerate them. However, I agree that being autistic can impair a persons ability to drive.

------------------------------

Right. And again, I'm not denying that being autistic can make it more difficult. I'm simply saying that society brings those issues into play in the first place.

------------------------------

I don't. However, considering the common advantages seen among the autistic population in relation to intellectual abilities, there's a very high chance that being autistic played a significant role.

------------------------------

Well, with one advantage comes a disadvantage. It's how humans work. We sacrifice certain areas to improve others.

There are always exceptions. You just so happen to be an outlier, and that's fine.

------------------------------

It's essentially just me trying to prove that differences aren't often very well accepted if they're significant. However, in personal experience, I've spoken to several people that are seemingly of high intelligence, yet with no diagnosed neurological or mental conditions, and the majority report poor social experiences, more specifically relating to being accepted. They simply didn't fit in with their hardcore logical mindsets.

Now, even though I'm autistic, I have personally experienced rejection for being overly-analytical. I've had many people aggressively ask why I have to make things more complicated than they are, which has led to social rejection. Barely anyone I've met seems to tolerate me being overly-analytical. In all honesty, I'm lucky to be introverted, but it's still annoying to know that people possess such mindsets when they reject others.

Your culture may simply be different to the one I live in.

------------------------------

The thing with neurotypical humans is that they constantly claim that we need to move away from normalcy, yet go on to create a broader definition of normalcy that people still have to fit in for them to be accepted. Witnessing this behaviour has made me suicidal in the past. Of course, even autistic people do that to a certain extent, but nowhere near on the level of significance of what's often seen in the neurotypical population.

------------------------------

Not necessarily. Whilst false stereotypes of autism still exist, there are genuine advantages present in most of us that some neurotypical people wish they had.

I've had one or two people say that they were jealous of my ability to notice small details and compile research data efficiently, and then have stated that they wish to be autistic at times. And no, that's not me trying to boost my ego; I'm saying that I personally know of some people that genuinely wish they were autistic.

------------------------------

Whilst I understand your point of view, I don't perceive it to be objectively truthful. Autism is your entire brain, shapes every thought process, influences your preferred interests, alters your social skills, alters your perception of various details, reduces intuition, enhances logical ability, and changes your preference for people. Objectively, autism is quite literally your entire personality. Without being autistic, you'd be nowhere near the person you are currently. Whilst you can believe otherwise, it's not necessarily possible to change the fact that you're essentially what autism is.

text: It‚Äôs both. I don‚Äôt like people who are on either extreme. I‚Äôm no Autism speaks supporter, but I‚Äôm not one to say that I‚Äôm not disabled. We‚Äôre not less, but we still need to accept that we are still impaired by it. The pros outweigh the cons, but no one has all the pros, and no cons, and vice versa.

author: HappyPiano

text:
¬†@Saturn¬† 
Of course, but Autism is a disability, it‚Äôs just ALSO part of our identity. We should be proud of our strengths, especially ones created by our Autism, but don‚Äôt become so prideful that the weaknesses creep into places you wouldn‚Äôt think of. I stand perfectly in the middle of identity belief, and disease belief, but either extreme just seems like too much.
author: HappyPiano

text:
¬†@HappyPiano¬† And that's not my implication. My implication is that most of the severe sensory issues experienced by us are caused by artificial environments, therefore, it'd be illogical and ignorant to attribute them exclusively to the state of being autistic, as the cause is quite obviously not autism, but rather the structure of said environments. It's fairly obvious.

Autism in itself is just as much a disability as being neurotypical, black, religious, or gay is. All of these groups have aspects of which are intrinsically disabling to a certain extent.

Just because something gives one weaknesses, it doesn't mean it's disordered or disabled generally. That's like saying "being left handed makes functioning slightly more difficult, therefore, it's a disability all-round".

For example: neurotypicals are often disabled by hyper-social conformity, group thinking, irrational decision making, and an increased tendency to bully others.

We're disabled by sensory sensitivity in certain situations, a lack of typical social skills, and general rigidity.

However, being autistic often comes with advantages, just as neurotypicality does.

They seem pretty equal to me, albeit with neurotypicals being more adaptable by default, hence why they tend to better-function in society.

author: john milligan

text: ¬†@Monotonous Insomniac¬† It got LGBTs and POC somewhere! I never suffered because of my asperger's but because of people's attitude to that diagnosis. Maybe it's time to fight back the way LGBTs and POC do? As some people with Asperger's have said, I don't feel disabled. On the contrary, I've always felt (even before my diagnosis) that I was too clever/sensitive/good for this society of shallow and selfish dimwits. Just look at how Greta is dismissed by a lot of public commentators on the basis of her asperger's. Doesn't that prove that: 1) A lot of NTs are "disabled", cuz they r blinded by their bigotry and desire to fit in at all cost, and don't see what actually matters, e.g. Greta's message, climate change. (my point being, NTs also have weaknesses) 2) People with asperger's suffer a lot of bullying and abuse, which just wouldn't fly nowadays if the same happened to POC or LGBTs. It's time to take a stand against "ableism" or simply "differencism" (cuz I for one don't feel disabled or "less than").
author: Baba Boubou

text: ¬†@Baba Boubou¬† The way to do that is this: Instead of complaining that the market is rigged and that we're discriminated against, let's get together and start a business and create opportunities. Instead of complaining about lack of or inaccurate representation in the media, let's get together and create a show that gives us accurate representation rather than sitting down begging and crying for it. And reject the public school system and pursue homeschooling and other forms of education that allows us to pursue and make good use of our limited interests. Government just makes things worse if you ask me and shouldn't be the solution to our problems. Sure you might not feel disabled, but there are "low-functioning" Autistics who have more severe symptoms and I feel as if the Autism community fails to acknowledge and address these Autistics. And I know this may sound hard, but "neurotypicals" arent born to understand Autistic people. It's not always "ableism", it's human nature.

text: God Bless Greta...but I am very skeptical about her Asperger's diagnosis.  I have been a practicing speech pathologist for 49 years and have observed many children on the Autism Spectrum.  From listening to this interview I observed the following to support my skepticism:  excellent eye contact, topic appropriate and accurate responses to questions, topic maintenance, no ritualistic or perseverative terms/language, appropriate facial expression, sense of humor (giggled appropriately), picked up on social cues,  emotion and empathy, understanding and use of figurative language, no idiosyncratic terms or word repetitions, prosody, intonational pattern and pitch within normal limits. NOTHING AT ALL TO INDICATE ASPERGER S.   Here's what I DO  concede: she is extremely verbose/and possibly OCD with climate change, but that alone does not constitute a diagnosis of Asperger's.  I read she was previously diagnosed with ADHD, OCD and selective mutism (which can be part of Asperger's. In the snippet with the large group of children, she did not look overwhelmed which seemed strange to me as a child described as socially awkward.    I observe her to be a bright, shy and articulate young lady from a theatrical background, dad was an actor, mom was an opera singer and grandpa was an actor/producer.  Perhaps these theatrical genes are the real GIFTS!

text:
Climate emergency: world 'may have crossed tipping points‚Äô

Warning of ‚Äòexistential threat to civilisation‚Äô as impacts lead to cascade of unstoppable events

The world may already have crossed a series of climate tipping points, according to a stark warning from scientists. This risk is ‚Äúan existential threat to civilisation‚Äù, they say, meaning ‚Äúwe are in a state of planetary emergency‚Äù.

Tipping points are reached when particular impacts of global heating become unstoppable, such as the runaway loss of ice sheets or forests. In the past, extreme heating of 5C was thought necessary to pass tipping points, but the latest evidence suggests this could happen between 1C and 2C.

The planet has already heated by 1C and the temperature is certain to rise further, due to past emissions and because greenhouse gas levels are still rising. The scientists further warn that one tipping point, such as the release of methane from thawing permafrost, may fuel others, leading to a cascade.

The researchers, writing in a commentary article in the journal Nature, acknowledge that the complex science of tipping points means great uncertainty remains. But they say the potential damage from the tipping points is so big and the time to act so short, that ‚Äúto err on the side of danger is not a responsible option‚Äù. They call for urgent international action.

‚ÄúA saving grace is that the rate at which damage accumulates from tipping could still be under our control to some extent,‚Äù they write. ‚ÄúThe stability and resilience of our planet is in peril. International action ‚Äì not just words ‚Äì must reflect this.‚Äù

Prof Tim Lenton at the University of Exeter, the lead author of the article, said: ‚ÄúWe might already have crossed the threshold for a cascade of interrelated tipping points. The simple version is the schoolkids [striking for climate action] are right: we are seeing potentially irreversible changes in the climate system under way, or very close.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs a scientist, I just want to tell it how it is,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is not trying to be alarmist, but trying to treat the whole climate change problem as a risk management problem. It is what I consider the common sense way.‚Äù

Phil Williamson at the University of East Anglia, who did not contribute to the article, said: ‚ÄúThe prognosis by Tim Lenton and colleagues is, unfortunately, fully plausible: that we might have already lost control of the Earth‚Äôs climate.‚Äù

The new article comes as the UN warns action is very far from stopping global temperature rise, with the world currently on track for 3C-4C. The commentary lists nine tipping points that may have been activated.

‚ÄúWe have this alarming evidence that part of the west Antarctic ice sheet may be in irreversible retreat,‚Äù said Lenton. ‚ÄúAll the signals are that it is.‚Äù A similar situation appears to be occurring at the Wilkes basin in east Antarctica. The collapse of these ice sheets would eventually raise sea level by many metres.

The massive Greenland ice sheet was melting at an accelerating rate, the scientists said, while Arctic sea ice is shrinking fast. ‚ÄúPermafrost across the Arctic is beginning to irreversibly thaw and release carbon dioxide and methane,‚Äù they said.

The Gulf Stream current in the Atlantic, which warms Europe, has also slowed by 15% since the mid-20th century. ‚ÄúThat is just about in the range of natural variability, but it is also hard to rule out that it is part of a longer downturn,‚Äù Lenton said.

The scientists report that 17% of the Amazon rainforest has been lost since 1970. The tipping point, where loss of forest leads to it drying out, could lie in the range 20%-40%, they said. In temperate forests, especially in North America, heating has triggered more fires and pest outbreaks, potentially turning some regions from a sink for carbon to a source. In the tropics, corals are predicted to be wiped out by 2C of heating.

A cascade of tipping points could occur because, for example, the melting of Arctic sea ice amplifies heating by exposing dark ocean that absorbs more sunlight. That may increase the melting of Greenland ice and permafrost areas. ‚ÄúMultiple risks can interact, with one change reinforcing another, and with warming of just a degree or two sufficient to result in dramatic cascading effects,‚Äù said Williamson.

Prof Martin Siegert, at Imperial College London, said: ‚ÄúThe new work is valuable. They are being a little speculative, but maybe you need to be.‚Äù He pointed out that the extremely rapid rate at which CO2 was being pumped into the atmosphere was unlikely to have ever occurred on Earth before. ‚ÄúIt may mean that tipping points can occur in unexpected ways as there is no geological precedent for this rate of CO2 change.‚Äù

The article reports that preliminary results from the latest climate models suggest global heating will be greater than expected, increasing the risk of tipping points. Prof Piers Forster, at the University of Leeds, disagreed on that point. However, he added: ‚ÄúI completely endorse their call for action. Although possibly low probability, the risks they identify are real.‚Äù

Lenton said action would still have real benefits, by slowing the impacts and giving more time for people to adapt. He said: ‚ÄúThis article is not meant to be a counsel of despair. If we want to avoid the worst of these bad climate tipping points, we need to activate some positive social and economic tipping points [such as renewable energy] towards what should ultimately be a happier, flourishing, sustainable future for the generations to come.‚Äù

text: ¬†@Erika¬† It hasn't been the easiest thing in the world. It may sound weird but when someone signals something or use metaphorical language I ask what they mean even if I know what it means. I do this because my knowledge of the signals and body language comes not from the natural instincts that allistic people develop but from learning it, and having to actively think about it (for example compare someone's facial expression to similar expressions I've seen and in what context they were made). It is more honest to do that. I don't want to give off the impression that i understand non verbal cues. And just because I hate pretending and have a very hard time being dishonest or saying white lies.

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

text:
This lazy truant is blemishing the reputation of good, in general, ecologic ideas, by reducing them to absurdity, and discredits those children with developmental peculiarities who try to study and work despite their diseases. Greta insolently boasts (!) about her extremism - which is not surprising; because a clever person MUST know dialectics - one more step in the same direction, and a thing changes to contrary.
In the former USSR, there were so called SUBBOTNIKS, that is Saturday (subbota) work events during which adults and schoolchildren tidied up the surroundings, planted trees and flowers. Nowadays subbotniks still exist as voluntary events. NOT INSTEAD OF THE LESSONS, but on weekends or at any other free time. At her age, we studied and helped adults, and we do not feel that our childhood was stolen. As children grow, they have not only rights, but also responsibilities according to their capabilities.
So dear Greta, do not learn to be a hypocrite by blaming people for their economic development and, at the same time, voyaging on an expensive yacht made of modern materials. Instead of your empty talks, take a spade, plant trees and collect garbage WITH YOUR OWN HANDS AFTER SCHOOL, NOT INSTEAD of it. You are not a little child any more, you already MUST do something, and not only demand it from others. Show your concern about the nature IN PRACTICE, and not only verbally, if you want us to beleive in the sincerety of your intentions. And without rushing into extremes, please, because fanaticism in evil. Labor therapy will be good for your brain.

text:
Okay, she had her moment of fame and her bag of attention....
Now it's time for the world leaders to adress the environmental problems more realistically.
Unfortunately, governments do not have the luxury to spend all their attention and resources on a single problem.
Her mind is too rigid to realize that the world doesn't work like that, only HER world works like that.


She obviously does not take into account that most 3rd world countries do not have the resources to invest billions in alternative energy and transportation.
She clearly doesn't care about people that rely on gasoline operated machinery and cars to sustain their livelyhood and to support their families...  and that a lot of those people cannot afford an electric alternative, if there's even an alternative available at all.
Imagine what happens to food prices if farmers are forced to switch to expensive and inefficient machinery to cultivate their crops and how many extra powerplants we're go√≠ng to need to supply the increased demand for electricity.
A mere 10% is supplied by renewable energy sources, most is coming from fossil fuel-powered plants or nuclear plants....  windturbines are not feasible without government funds and solar panels are inefficient while their manufacturing puts a great burden on the environment.


It's not just about the luxury we have to sacrifice....  the drastic changes, within the "demanded" timeframe she advocates are go√Øng to affect people's access to basic needs, like food, education and employment; what about their children?  What about their dreams and childhood?
She's clearly growing up in a prosperous country and has the luxury to skip school and speak before the U.N., while a lot of kids her age around the world don't even have a school to skip.


Eventhough climate change is a fact and should be ignored, people must not forget that she has several mental conditions.... no offense meant here; but it's a fact that also cannot be ignored.
She has OCD, Asperger's syndrome, ADHD and autism and while this doesnt make her any less of a person; it must be taken into account that it does affect her rationality, logic and reasoning.
Her ideas are very biased and rigid (black-and-white thinking) and if people will follow that example and she gets her way, then we will only replace one problem with another and the global support for measures on climate change will deteriorate.


She brought her message, she repeated it over and over again...  it's in people's system now.
Now it's time for governments to take over the concept and continue with reasoning and logic; while it's time to protect Greta from herself and the activists that (ab)use her as a spokesperson.
She's 16 y/o, she should be in school and she needs guidance to look after her mental health, let the grown ups take it from here and within a few years she can be proud of the improvements that were made thanks to her.

text:
Come privato cittadino sto pagando un debito che ho contratto per l'acquisto di un pianoforte: all'esaurimento delle rate avr√≤ restituito l'importo iniziale ricevuto pi√π gli interessi sul medesimo.
Ma lo stato non funziona in questo modo.
Anzitutto, impone tasse, il che significa che tutti i soldi che spende rientrano, nel tempo, nelle sue casse: se lo Stato ha speso 100 euro, ogni volta che il prenditore li spende una frazione di quei soldi rientra fiscalmente, e sommando tutte le frazioni successive si vede bene che il residuo non rientrato tende progressivamente a zero. Quindi gli stessi soldi continuano ad uscire e rientrare nelle tasche, alternativamente, dello Stato e dei cittadini: si tratta sempre della stessa liquidit√† che scorre senza sosta dall'uno all'altro.
Ma avendo lo stato preso i soldi in prestito, compare un'alta differenza alla scadenza del credito usato: mentre il cittadino deve ripagare i propri debiti, lo stato non lo fa (nessuno Stato lo fa mai), perch√© semplicemente lo rinnova (rimborsa un TdS e ne emette un altro identico, mantenendo quindi sempre la stessa cifra disponibile).
Naturalmente deve corrispondere gli interessi, ma nemmeno questo √® un vero problema: basta infatti emettere un secondo nuovo TdS per pagarlo.
.Ci√≤ significa che alla scadenza di ogni credito il debito pubblico aumenta di una percentuale pari agli interessi corrisposti.
La differenza tra uno Stato che dispone di un compratore di ultima istanza (come eravamo noi fino al 1981) ed uno che non lo ha sta nel fatto che nel primo caso √® lo Stato a decidere il valore dell'interesse (tassi di sconto), come facevamo in passato noi, e come fa tutt'oggi il Giappone, mentre nel secondo caso lo decidono i creditori (cio√® le banche che acquistano i TdS).
Ma tenendo contro che "debito pubblico" significa "I soldi che abbiamo in tasca" e che lo Stato non lo ripaga mai, perch√© solo lo rinnova, dobbiamo concludere che la questione del debito di Stato non √® "un problema"; bens√¨ solo uno spauracchio per ingenui.

text:
The Thunberg family has writ a book: This is the story of a family led to confront a crisis they had never foreseen. Aged eleven, their eldest daughter has stopped eating and speaking. Alongside diagnoses of autism and selective mutism, her parents slowly become aware of another source for her distress: her imperilled future on a rapidly heating planet.
Steered by her determination to understand the truth, the family begins to see the deep connections between their own and the planet‚Äôs suffering. Against forces that try to silence them, disparaging them for being different, they discover ways to strengthen, heal, and act in the world. And then one day, fifteen-year-old Greta decides to go on strike.
author: Rose White

The grandchildren of rich people, middle-class people and poor people alike, will equally suffer early deaths from emphysema, radiation sickness and cancer. text:
This Earth Management Committee cannot work for the glory of peace; but there is a way. The reason nations are not anxious to join in on Climate Change and Global Warming is because of differences of opinion. All recognize we have a problem, but we do not agree that taxing the population and bringing it under strict control is the solution. Freedom is a most precious calming influence on mankind; it gives us power to think clearly and maintain an active relationship with our neighbors and our government. When freedom is lost, even for what is seen as important reasons, it destroys incentive and excitement in life.

The reason the United Nations and the Sustainable Development arm with Agenda 21 etc. have been unsuccessful in getting solutions to what is called "Global Warning" and "Climate Change" is because they do not have the authority to implement "forced behavioral modifications." That is what Mikhail Gorbachev stated when efforts had not been successful after several years. The goal of the World Integrated Administrative World Government system seems to be the "establishing of a STRONG UNIFIED leadership center" which would make their decisions mandatory, an obligation with penalties for failure to comply being the power for the "forced behavioral modification" needed.

We destroy our atmosphere, making it dangerous to man and planet with our modern lifestyle and pride. We left our little family farms to become great in the city, not realizing we were separating the joy of family, outdoor life, food giving animals and trees and vegetation that gave us fresh food for healthy, stress free, bodies. It is NOW that we can see what we lost as we seek promise of "health care for all" to pay for the sure diseases we expect. Our energy use in our small communities was spread out so the impact was not so dramatic and harmful to man and planet, we used renewable energy of trees. Now we are in cities ... our foods are transported in; the electric and gas power of thousands + of our apartments, homes, businesses and automobiles is concentrated within (?) 30 miles; and then we must use vast amounts of polluting energy to travel (occasionally) to see our loved ones. This is an easy problem to fix; just back out of our system. Moms were home, teaching their children and cooking their foods, and teaching the values of our Creator and society, showing the youth how to become good sons and daughters and parents and citizens; that alone corrects most of the ills of our society.

text:
I can remember when we were constantly being given warnings by "scientific experts"  that we were entering a new ice age. I believe this was in the late seventies. There were doom-laden documentaries telling us that the science proving this ice age was coming was settled. There may in fact be something to this idea because the whole period in which civilisations have developed up to the present could be just a temporary warm period (interstitial) within the last ice age.
There is nothing new or particularly surprising about climate change. There was in fact a period of time called the Mediaeval Warm Period which was a period of progress and prosperity. It lasted from the mid 10th century to the mid 13th century. Varieties of grape suitable for making red wine were successfully grown in England at this time.
We  later had a prolongued cold period called the "Little Ice Age" when "frost fairs" were regularly held on the frozen ice of the Thames and other northern European rivers  from the 17th century to the beginning of the nineteenth century. 
Dramatic climate changes have happened historically without human activity being a significant factor. The single greatest influence on changes in climate has always been the sun.

text: Tell that to the people in miami beach my guy.  They now routinely have flooding on sunny days and have spent billions on water pumping systems as a result.  The temperature has also gone up, it's not hard to measure.  What you're witnessing outside btw is called weather.  So far the planet's temperature has only increased by around 1 degree, which is not something your body can perceive!  But for the entire planet, small differences matter.  Think about the difference between a career .275 hitter vs career .300 hitter in baseball.  On any given day the .300 hitter can go hitless and the .275 hitter can get 3 hits.  The .275 hitter might even have a higher batting average than the .300 hitter in a given season!  If you just watched each player hit - without keeping track - it would be very difficult to notice which player is recording more hits.  The difference is only 1 extra hit for every 40 at bats!  This is similar to the type of temperature increase we're experiencing.  It's hard to tell the difference between 57 degrees farenheit and 59 degrees, but on a planetary scale it has major effects!

text:
¬†@LWT¬† I wasn't saying that depression and anxiety makes you less rational and more delusional.  It makes no difference whether you are aware of them in yourself or not.  It just means that they will colour your beliefs or what you are told, and if you find somethings in the world, or within you to be personally worrying, then your depression and anxiety will magnify them into something potentially terrifying.  
If you are not aware of the problem, then it is up to others to help you through it, not encourage it by parading you in front of the world and feeding your negativity.  If you are aware of it, then you can also be aware that it is wrong to go around creating anxietys in other kids and "stealing their childhood" too (whatever that means, it is a pretty nonsense comment.)  
News reports on the demonstrations have shown 12-13 year old kids crying and sobbing because they believe that all the animals are dying, and we are all going to fry  and die in 12 years time.  To foster that  reaction in kids is evil.  Can you imagine their nightmares when they ate alone in the dark at night with just their own thoughts.  It is not right to do that to a child
Anyone who was a kid in the Cuban Missile Crisis will know what I am talking about.  The CMC was a reality,  frying in 12 years is not  And the current extinction of species has little to do with climate change, it is due to Habitat encroachment and destruction by our species at the expense of others.

text:
¬†@Dawa¬† If you believe that very warm leads to very cold, that is lunacy.  We are in an Ice Age cycle, not a warm cycle.  These cycles, for the last 3 million years has short warm and very long cold cycles.  It does NOT get 'warmer and warmer' at the end of a warm cycle, all warm cycles show sudden, strong warming and then declining temperatures until plunging into an increasingly cold Ice Age.  

So it is today: our 'warm cycle' is much colder than three previous warm cycles, the Minoan, Roman and Medieval warm cycles.  All of these were cooler than the pre-civilization warm cycles and the very early Egyptian warm cycle 8,000 years ago.

text:
Why cut her off? How rude can you get? They asked some fluff questions, then the one question that mattered, what should we do about it, they cut her off. Did they not want to know? Here's what she was saying:
Learn a little of the science. Read this two-page summary from NASA, NOAA and others: https://science2017.globalchange.gov/chapter/executive-summary/
There is scientific consensus about these conclusions - that means it's time to act on them: http://climate.nasa.gov/scientific-consensus
There are simple policies to address the main problem, like Carbon Fee and Dividend: http://citizensclimatelobby.org/basics-carbon-fee-dividend
To get Congress to act, we need a million or two people to send them an  email every week. You can do that easily from here: http://cclusa.org/write
And please pass it on.

text: Greta's parents were busy pursuing their demanding careers and were largely unaware of the climate change debate. It was Greta who studied the evidence presented by the climate scientists, and educated her parents and sister on the subject. Yes, she did go through depression when she realized the enormity of the issue. But, Greta changed the entire lifestyle of her family. They became environmentally-conscious and vegetarians. Her parents scaled back their careers and stopped travelling by air. Her father is now heavily involved with Greta's climate activist work. It's been Greta running the show from the beginning. People tend to judge Greta by her youth and unassuming demeanor, and therefore they vastly underestimate her integrity, intellect, and drive. She is a child in years only. In terms of maturity, I'd say she's 40 to 50.

Now first, this time you're absolutely right!
Creating a society fueled by renewable energy will also do harm.
It will probably destroy some landscapes, drive inhabitants from their home, harm animals or even extinguish some species.

text:
@Neptunus9  
   Google is not a credible source for information, they have an agenda aligned with the globalist climate doom and gloom hoax. They are complicit in the censorship of information. 
   
Yes, man made climate change is a hoax. It‚Äôs not settled  or established science. A consensus of scientists is not science at all. Science does not rely on democracy. Definition of science-the intellectual and practical activity encompassing the systematic study of the structure and behaviour of the physical and natural world through observation and experiment. Falsifying and omitting data is not science. 

To be clear, the earth is an celestial oblate spheroid and not flat by any means. Fools won with truth.
  Natural climate change is established and it shows no change due to human intervention. All that‚Äôs required is to look at the full record and the understanding of historical placement of thermometers. 

You‚Äôre still welcome to perceive me as a fool but once it was established the earth was the center of the universe. Fools fought back with truth and won. It was also once established drilling holes in someone‚Äôs head would release evil spirits. How did that consensus turn out? Fools won with truth again. 
   
I can only suggest you think for yourself, do your own research and running with the herd often places an open mind at a disadvantage. 

I‚Äôve listened to climate alarmists for 40 years without one prediction being remotely correct. Natural climate change is real, I do not contest. But if humans are so arrogant to believe they can have a meaningful effect by fleecing the wealth from individuals, fools we all are. 
Good luck on your journey for truth, knowledge, wisdom and happiness. 

Green is the new marketed imperialism, I‚Äôll have no part.

text: @Neptunus9 I‚Äôm not sorry but haranguing and name calling has no effect but to expose your closed mind. Being correct is not my end game. I would prefer to be wrong and learn something. author: Kyle G

text:
¬†@Kyle G¬† Hey Kyle, hope your doing well. Um...where to begin.
Well, lets start out with your first claim that climate change is man made i a hoax. Science have clear evidence that global warming is man made. Earth‚Äôs temperatures are currently warming 20 to 50 times faster than when the planet exits an ice age, for example. No natural cycle can account for the current rapid global warming. This theory, and I assume you know what the word "theory" means in world of science, is agreed upon in the science community. You claim about falsifying data, yes it has happened a few times that data has been distorted. But the major bulk of the data, at least the data that the IPCC has taken part of, is 100% validated. If you dispute that, you have the burden of proof.
The world is also full of signs of human made climate change. In its Fifth Assessment Report, the IPCC, the  group of 1,300 independent scientific experts from countries all over the world under the auspices of the United Nations, concluded there's a more than 95 percent probability that human activities over the past 50 years have warmed our planet.
Please read the report, its right here: https://www.ipcc.ch/reports/
Also, your examples of historical foolishness does not apply to my arguements. Not any of the examples you mentioned could back up their theories with science. The drilling of holes to release spirits sounds more religous and ocult than anything else, so I am sure you agree the example is not the best.  
For your own and your childrens future, I hope you do read the IPCC reports. Its the worlds most competent people that have studied he topic and we need to pay attention to what they are saying.

text:
Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), which peaked about 55 million years ago. Global temperatures during this event may have warmed by 5¬∞C to 8¬∞C within a few thousand years, with the Arctic Ocean reaching a subtropical 23¬∞C. Mass extinctions resulted.

In between ice ages, some lesser peaks of temperature have occurred a number of times, especially around 125,000 years ago. At this time, temperatures may have been about 1¬∞C to 2¬∞C degrees warmer than today. Sea level was 5 to 8 metres higher than today ‚Äì a rise sufficient to inundate most of the world‚Äôs coastal cities.This peak was triggered by the orbital cycles.

text: Yes, the climate has  been naturally warming and cooling long before humans came along, but right now human activity is contributing to the warming. We are adding 100 million tons of CO2 to the atmosphere daily and we've cut down over a trillion trees so the absorption of CO2 by nature is less. Natural changes in the climate occur over millions of years.  Right now, the climate is warming about 170 times faster that it ever did before.
author: Computerworks

text: ¬†@Lucid Dreamer¬† It will take trillions of dollars over decades to deal with climate change and only governments have that kind of money. First, we will need to retrofit carbon capture modifications into all the electric power plants that burn coal and gas in order to reduce the CO2 emissions. At the same time, we will need to build carbon removal plants at many locations throughout the world. These plants will remove carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere. But, the governments won't act unless enough people (voters) wake up to the danger and push for action. So, the climate activists are trying to mobilize more and more people into joining the cause. If nothing is done to mitigate climate warming, most of humanity probably will be gone before 2100, according to climate scientists. Yes, it's that bad. Even with very urgent action, we will see mass migrations away from drought-stricken and flooded regions; famine on a biblical scale; mass extinctions of plants, insects, and animals; and conflicts over the world's remaining resources. All of these effects are well under way, and we have already waited too long to avert a catastrophic die-off of the population.  And, the longer we wait, the WORSE IT WILL BE.
